titleStmt.title: Charles H. Phillips v. William Billings. Answer

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.title: Charles H. Phillips v. William Billings. Answer
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: In the District Court Of the Second Judicial District of Washington Territory, holding terms at Olympia for the Counties of Thurston and Mason
Territory of Washington vs. C H Phillips
Defendant and petitioner for answer to the return of the Sheriff herein says.

Petitioner says that the said Justice Keady had no power or right to order petitioner committed to jail as is stated in said return in this. The evidence taken before said Justice was not reduced to writing as required by statute. And no evidence before Justice which tended to make a case of probable cause against defendant

That said justice has frequently stated, as petitioner is informed and believes that there was no sufficient evidence in said case against petitioner. That said justice in a heat of passion, without any evidence, ordered petitioner to be committed.
That the bail fixed by said justice is fixed at one hundred dollars, and at no sums as shown by the docket of said justice.

That your petitioner did not commit the larceny complained of nor any larceny, nor any other crime. Wherefore petitioner prays that he be allowed to offer evidence showing his innocence and that he be hence discharged
D P Ballard Atty for Petitioner
Territory of Washington, County of Thurston } ss

being first duly sworn, on oath, says: That he is the Petitioner named in the above entitled action: that he has heard the foregoing answer read, knows the contents thereof, and believes the same to be true
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 2 day of August 1884 D P Ballard Notary Public for Washington Territory
Territory of Washington vs. Charles H Phillips
Received and Filed Aug 2 1884 R.G. O'Bruin
